nodes.text: Increasing sleep among urban poor affects economic outcomes such as productivity, labor supply, cognition, preferences, and well-being

Method: Measured sleep objectively with wrist actigraphy in two Chennai samples and ran a randomized controlled trial (N=452) cross-randomizing night-sleep treatments (devices+encouragement, devices+incentives, control) with an offered 30-minute daily workplace nap

Evidence (baseline): Low-income adults in Chennai sleep about 5.5 hours/night on average while spending ~8 hours in bed; sleep efficiency ~70% with ~31 awakenings per night, resembling clinical sleep-disorder levels

Result (intervention on night sleep): Night-sleep treatments increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes/night on average (driven entirely by increased time in bed ~38 minutes) but did not increase sleep efficiency
Result (nap intervention): The offered workplace nap increased daytime sleep by ~14 minutes/day on average (high take-up; naps in office had higher sleep efficiency than night sleep)
Evidence: Increasing nighttime sleep required more time in bed because low sleep efficiency persisted; raising one minute of sleep required ~1.4 minutes in bed

Result: Pooled night-sleep treatment produced no significant improvements in overall index or family-level indices (work, well-being, cognition, preferences) and had no significant positive effect on any individual outcome other than sleep itself

Result: Naps improved the overall summary index by 0.12 standard deviations and significantly improved productivity, psychological well-being, and lab measures of cognition, while reducing work time during the nap period
Result: Night-sleep increases led to reduced labor supply (~9 minutes/day) and small nonsignificant decreases in earnings, rejecting expert predictions of sizable output gains

Evidence/Comparison: Per-minute instrumental-variable estimates indicate minutes of nap sleep have more positive effects per minute on the overall index, cognition, and psychological well-being than minutes of nighttime sleep, but naps crowd out more work time per minute

Method/Evidence: Surveyed 119 experts in sleep science and economics who predicted substantive economic gains from a half-hour increase in night sleep, enabling comparison between priors and RCT outcomes

Claim/Explanation: Possible reasons for null effects of increased night sleep include (a) poor sleep quality (low efficiency and fragmented sleep) reducing marginal returns, and (b) lab-based severe deprivation experiments not generalizing to modest, real-world increases

Conclusion and policy implication: Increasing nighttime sleep via more time in bed produced little short-run economic benefit in this context, while providing comfortable workplace naps produced meaningful gains; naps may be an effective intervention but generalizability and long-term effects require further field study

Limitation: Study duration was short (three-week treatment window), conducted in one urban low-income setting and one work context (data-entry job), limiting external validity and ability to detect longer-run physical-health effects

Recommendation/Assumption: Future research should test interventions that improve sleep efficiency or housing/environmental constraints, examine long-term health outcomes, and assess naps versus nighttime sleep timing and quality across diverse contexts
